messages: 487c399908fb663a16b84718c3403136 (15:34): shell script of the day:
487c399908fb663a16b84718c3403136 (15:34): while true; do printf "\033[2t"; printf "\033[1t"; done
f38ed10caa29ff4ae88c1bd4306d7ae4 (15:37): while true..
f38ed10caa29ff4ae88c1bd4306d7ae4 (15:38): printf "\033[2t"; printf "\033[1t"; < minimize my term on wmaker, funny
487c399908fb663a16b84718c3403136 (15:39): some terminals take control codes and some don't
487c399908fb663a16b84718c3403136 (15:39): it's better to printf them than to echo them in any case
f38ed10caa29ff4ae88c1bd4306d7ae4 (15:39): xterm and Eterm are minimized
f38ed10caa29ff4ae88c1bd4306d7ae4 (15:40): The echo utility is expected to be IEEE Std 1003.2 (``POSIX.2'') compati-
f38ed10caa29ff4ae88c1bd4306d7ae4 (15:40): ble.
f38ed10caa29ff4ae88c1bd4306d7ae4 (15:40): The printf utility conforms to IEEE Std 1003.1-2001 (``POSIX.1'').
f38ed10caa29ff4ae88c1bd4306d7ae4 (15:40): no bug for echo
f38ed10caa29ff4ae88c1bd4306d7ae4 (15:40): bug for printf
487c399908fb663a16b84718c3403136 (15:43): well unless i'm a dummy and you can do octal escape \033 in echo
487c399908fb663a16b84718c3403136 (15:43): then it's better to do it in printf
487c399908fb663a16b84718c3403136 (15:43): more human readable
487c399908fb663a16b84718c3403136 (15:43): better to script you with, my dear
487c399908fb663a16b84718c3403136 (15:45): anyway if it was fully compliant, it would restore immediately upon minimizing
487c399908fb663a16b84718c3403136 (15:46): that's what [1t is supposed to do
f38ed10caa29ff4ae88c1bd4306d7ae4 (15:46): printf "\033[2t"; < just that minimize for me
f38ed10caa29ff4ae88c1bd4306d7ae4 (15:47): you can replace printf by echo -n
f38ed10caa29ff4ae88c1bd4306d7ae4 (15:47): it doesn't really change so many things
f38ed10caa29ff4ae88c1bd4306d7ae4 (15:47): it is just another standard command
f38ed10caa29ff4ae88c1bd4306d7ae4 (15:47): i don't really understand why you focus on printf
f38ed10caa29ff4ae88c1bd4306d7ae4 (15:48): since it's old posix and buggy with float
f38ed10caa29ff4ae88c1bd4306d7ae4 (15:48): in the contrary of echo
f38ed10caa29ff4ae88c1bd4306d7ae4 (15:48): and they both print to std out
487c399908fb663a16b84718c3403136 (15:48): in my admittedly limited experience
f38ed10caa29ff4ae88c1bd4306d7ae4 (15:49): nevermind, i have echo 'your command' in a file :p
25340eebdcb1899fb0bfe8077b2afc00 (15:49): He guys
487c399908fb663a16b84718c3403136 (15:49): trying to embed an escape sequence in for example a .bashrc
25340eebdcb1899fb0bfe8077b2afc00 (15:49): Any of you know about this website called www.hi5.com ? Is it legit ?
487c399908fb663a16b84718c3403136 (15:49): is dangerous with echo because you have to type the actual escape character
487c399908fb663a16b84718c3403136 (15:49): so then if you just casually cat your .bashrc
f38ed10caa29ff4ae88c1bd4306d7ae4 (15:49): ah ok
487c399908fb663a16b84718c3403136 (15:49): suddenly escape sequences happen
f38ed10caa29ff4ae88c1bd4306d7ae4 (15:49): yep ok lol
487c399908fb663a16b84718c3403136 (15:49): and then you're like AAAGH WTF
f38ed10caa29ff4ae88c1bd4306d7ae4 (15:50): i understand now
487c399908fb663a16b84718c3403136 (15:50): that's really the only reason i prefer printf, for aliases
f38ed10caa29ff4ae88c1bd4306d7ae4 (15:50): but it's a particular case
487c399908fb663a16b84718c3403136 (15:50): anything more, and bugs show up
487c399908fb663a16b84718c3403136 (15:50): i use echo for everything else
487c399908fb663a16b84718c3403136 (15:50): text editing especially
f38ed10caa29ff4ae88c1bd4306d7ae4 (15:54): yep AZE=`echo blabla | tutut | plopplop|
f38ed10caa29ff4ae88c1bd4306d7ae4 (15:54): etc..
